article.headline: North Carolina State remains unbeaten
article.linkText: Wolfpack need late surge to beat Cajuns
article.story: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) -- Andrew Brackman provided the spark that North Carolina State (No. 9 ESPN/USA Today; No. 12 AP) so desperately needed Wednesday night. As a result, the 12th-ranked Wolfpack stayed unbeaten -- barely. The freshman scored a career-high 20 points and made several key plays during a decisive second-half run to lift N.C. State past Louisiana-Lafayette 78-72. Julius Hodge added 16 points for the Wolfpack (8-0), who overcame a horrendous first half and held on to stay unbeaten. Tiras Wade scored a career-high 37 points -- an RBC Center record -- and hit five 3-pointers to lead the Ragin' Cajuns (3-5), who hung around until the final seconds before falling short. The Wolfpack are off to their best start since going 9-0 in 1981-82, but they had to grind out a tough win against a determined opponent in a rematch of a first-round NCAA tournament game from last season. The Wolfpack won that game 61-52. N.C. State shot 15 for 22 in the second half and went 29 for 44 from the free throw line for the game, but was outrebounded 42-25. It also had to overcome foul trouble to starter Tony Bethel and a hip flexor that limited Jordan Collins after halftime. "We had a dose of adversity," N.C. State coach Herb Sendek said. "With all that being said, we found a way to get a 'W'." The lanky 6-foot-10 Brackman was a big reason why. With his team looking flat throughout the first half, Brackman jolted the Wolfpack to life after the break. After taking just one shot in the first half, Brackman finished 6-for-6 from the field with four rebounds and three blocked shots in 23 minutes. "Our team was on the ropes," Brackman said. "We needed somebody to step up, and every game somebody different has to step up. I just felt it was my time." Brackman's effort was enough to offset Wade's big day. With starting point guard Orien Greene out with a broken leg sustained in Saturday's 96-51 loss at No. 2 Kansas, Wade had 16 points in the first half and finished 13 for 26 from the field. His point total the previous building record of 32 set by Arizona State's Eddie House in 2000. "He tried to put the team on his back and carry us home," Louisiana-Lafayette coach Robert Lee said of Wade, who repeatedly made tough shots against Hodge and other Wolfpack defenders. Brackman's performance also offset a shaky performance from Hodge, the reigning Atlantic Coast Conference player of the year. The senior went just 6 for 14 at the line and committed five turnovers in what he considered an "awful" performance. "I've just got to play better than that," he said. Just about everything that could go wrong did for the Wolfpack in the first half. After a quick start, N.C. State shot 6 for 20, including 1 for 11 from 3-point range, and committed 10 turnovers to trail 28-23 at halftime. But Brackman drained a long 3 with the shot clock winding down for the Wolfpack's first score of the second half, a basket that ultimately foreshadowed his strong second-half performance. With his team trailing 48-47 midway through the second half, Brackman made probably his biggest play, reaching high above the rim for a missed 3-pointer from Ilian Evtimov and slamming it home with 10:23 left. "I didn't think I was going to get it," Brackman said of the high rebound. The dunk "was kind of weak." Weak or not, that basket seemed to energize a once-lethargic home crowd and started the Wolfpack on a 7-0 spurt that put them ahead to stay. From there, Brackman made his mark on both ends of the floor. He assisted on Levi Watkins' 3 from the right wing for a 52-48 lead on the next possession. He swatted shots on two straight possessions, further energizing a once-lethargic crowd. Then he got free inside for two baskets, scoring on a feed from Evtimov and spinning by Chris Cameron on the right block for a 58-52 lead with 6:40 to play. "That young guy can ball," Hodge said. "He shows a lot of heart and determination, and I like that." Louisiana-Lafayette hung around the rest of the way. Wade hit two free throws then made a contested, double-pump 3 to pull to 74-72 with 6.9 seconds to go. But Cameron Bennerman drained two free throws to put the game away. "It was adrenaline at that point," Wade said. "Some of those shots at the end were just lucky."
